awd_titl_txt: Reconstructing evolutionary history in adaptive radiations with genomic data
awd_abstract_narration:
Evolutionary biologists seek to understand why there is such tremendous diversity in life forms and how these diverse forms developed over time. One approach to addressing these questions is to study and compare the genetic makeup of closely related species. Some of life's most striking examples of diversity have evolved in a process known as adaptive radiation, when a wide variety of closely related species arise from a common ancestor during a relatively brief period of time. Adaptive radiations of cichlid fishes in certain African lakes provide captivating examples of this process, where these fishes exhibit incredible diversity in color, shape, and reproductive and feeding behaviors. Recently developed technologies make it easier to obtain large amounts of genetic data from wild organisms, so that it is now possible to document thousands of times more of the genetic makeup of these species than ever before. This project will use such genomic data to study the history of species that have formed in two African cichlid fish adaptive radiations, thus improving our understanding of how and why species have evolved, and yielding greater insight into the origins of biodiversity. In addition to its scientific goals, this work will strengthen relationships with international partners in Tanzania and the Democratic Republic of Congo through a collaborative workshop on the use of genetic data in understanding and monitoring biodiversity. It will also involve the development of educational materials for teaching about evolution and biodiversity in middle school classrooms.  

Adaptive radiations are exemplary systems for studying evolutionary processes due to the diversity of forms that evolve on rapid timescales. However, the rapid nature of these diversification events means that reconstructing the history of species divergence can be intensely challenging. The recent attainability of genome-wide sequence data for non-model organisms has precipitated a fundamental shift in the data that can be used to address questions related to the history of rapidly diversifying species. Such genomic datasets present new opportunities for uniting population genetics approaches with phylogenetic approaches to understand the history of species and speciation in adaptive radiation. This research will expand knowledge of how genomic data can aid in reconstructing the history of rapid adaptive radiations by studying two model cichlid adaptive radiations, Lake Kivu's haplochromine cichlids and Lake Tanganyika's tropheine cichlids. It will use newly available genomic resources to investigate the evolutionary history of these groups and the evolutionary processes influencing patterns of genetic diversity.

por.por_cntn:
In adaptive radiations, many species rapidly evolve from a common ancestor. These systems are useful for studying evolution because because of the substantial diversity that arises quickly. African cichlid fishes are exemplary cases of the process of adaptive radiation. However, the rapid nature of evolution means that reconstructing the history of species divergence can be intensely challenging. Recent advances in genomic DNA sequencing have precipitated a fundamental shift in the data that can be used to address questions related to the history of rapidly diversifying species. Genomic datasets present new opportunities for uniting population level studies of evolution with studies at the scale of evolutionary relationships among many species.  

In this project, our goal was to expand knowledge of how genomic data can aid in reconstructing the history of rapid adaptive radiations. We used advanced genetic techniques to analyze the DNA of fish species found in Lake Tanganyika and Lake Kivu. We generated substantial amounts of new genomic sequence data to investigate the evolutionary history of these groups and the evolutionary processes influencing genomic diversity. We collected new specimens and genetic resources from Lake Tanganyika through fieldwork funded by this grant, and combined these new collections with previously collected specimens from prior work in Lake Tanganyika. In Lake Kivu, we worked with previously collected specimens to generate new genomic data.

As a result of this grant, we advanced knowledge of the history of cichlid fishes in Lakes Kivu and Tanganyika. We identified new features in the history of these adaptive radiations. Specifically, we discovered that there was interbreeding between different lineages of fish in the past, which influenced the genetic diversity and composition of the fish in Lake Kivu. We also found evidence that natural selection played a role in shaping the genetic makeup of these fish after the interbreeding events. In Lake Tanganyika, we found evidence of interbreeding between different species and found that the prevalence of interbreeding varied depending on the location and abundance of fish populations. By combining genetic analysis with ecological data, we gained insights into the evolutionary processes that drove the rapid diversification of cichlid fish in Lake Tanganyika. In addition, we studied how the processing of genomic data influences evolutionary reconstruction, and identified best practices for these analyses that depend on the dataset and questions of interest.  

In addition to our scientific goals, our work contributed to workforce development through training students in bioinformatics and the analysis of genomic data. Furthermore, we strengthened relationships with international partners in Africa, and we hosted collaborative workshops on the use of genetic data in understanding and monitoring biodiversity in Tanzania. The African Great Lakes are ecosystems under severe threat due to lake warming, overfishing, and the imminent threat of species introductions. There is tremendous need to increase capacity for genetic monitoring of diversity in these systems among professionals working in fisheries management.

We worked to develop educational materials for teaching about evolution and biodiversity in middle school classrooms in Wyoming and elsewhere in the US. We targeted Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) for Evolution and Diversity for middle school classrooms, particularly targeting teaching of the concepts of descent with modification and common ancestry. This is timely due to the recent adoption of NGSS in Wyoming and pushes state-wide for alignment of the curriculum to these new standards. We directly trained K-12 teachers through teacher training workshops, and we are disseminating lesson plans and lesson materials widely across the state of Wyoming, as well as making the materials available online to teachers across the US.
